item.title: RP2040 Spins Right ‘Round inside POV Display
item.description: Sometimes, a flat display just won’t cut it. If you’re looking for something a little rounder, perhaps your vision could persist in in looking at [lhm0]’s rotating LED sphere RP2040 …read more

item.title: Hash Functions with the Golden Ratio
item.description: In the realm of computer science, it’s hard to go too far without encountering hashing or hash functions. The concept appears throughout security, from encryption to password storage to crypto, …read more

item.title: XOR Gate as a Frequency Doubler
item.description: [IMSAI Guy] grabbed an obsolete XOR gate and tried a classic circuit to turn it into a frequency doubler. Of course, being an old part, it won’t work at very …read more

item.title: New study shows why simulated reasoning AI models don’t yet live up to their billing
item.description: Top AI models excel at math problems but lack reasoning needed for Math Olympiad proofs.

item.title: FBI offers $10 million for information about Salt Typhoon members
item.description: FBI accepts tips by TOR in likely attempt to woo China-based informants.

item.title: Robot Gets a DIY Pneumatic Gripper Upgrade
item.description: [Tazer] built a small desktop-sized robotic arm, and it was more or less functional. However, he wanted to improve its ability to pick things up, and attaching a pneumatic gripper …read more

item.title: Sigrok Website Down After Hosting Data Loss
item.description: When it comes to open source signal analysis software for logic analyzers and many other sensors, Sigrok is pretty much the only game in town. Unfortunately after an issue with …read more

item.title: Hackaday Podcast Ep 318: DIY Record Lathe, 360 Degree LIDAR, and 3D Printing Innovation Lives!
item.description: This week Elliot Williams was joined by fellow Europe-based Hackaday staffer Jenny List, to record the Hackaday Podcast as the dusk settled on a damp spring evening. On the agenda …read more

item.title: You Wouldn’t Steal a Font…
item.description: In the 2000s, the DVD industry was concerned about piracy, in particular the threat to their business model presented by counterfeit DVDs and downloadable movies. Their response was a campaign …read more

item.title: In the age of AI, we must protect human creativity as a natural resource
item.description: Op-ed: As AI outputs flood the Internet, diverse human perspectives are our most valuable resource.

item.title: Grab bag! On the floor at HumanX
item.description: Today’s episode is a roundup of spontaneous, on-the-ground conversations from HumanX 2025, featuring guests from CodeConductor, DDN, Cloudflare, and Galileo.

item.title: New Android spyware is targeting Russian military personnel on the front lines
item.description: Trojanized mapping app steals users' locations, contacts, and more.

item.title: Standardization and simplification as key to engineering excellence
item.description: In this episode of Leaders of Code, we chat with guests from Lloyds Banking Group about their focus on engineering excellence and the need for organizations to adapt to new technologies while ensuring customer safety and meeting their expectations.

item.title: Community Products roadmap update, April 2025
item.description: An update on recent launches and the upcoming roadmap

item.title: Visually orchestrating data diagnostics but platform agnostic
item.description: Ryan chats with Dataiku CEO and cofounder Florian Douetteau about the complexities of the genAI data stack and how his company is orchestrating it.

item.title: Annoyed ChatGPT users complain about bot’s relentlessly positive tone
item.description: Users complain of new "sycophancy" streak where ChatGPT thinks everything is brilliant.

item.title: Generating components, not tokens
item.description: On today’s episode, Ben and Ryan chat with Laly Bar-Ilan, Chief Scientist at Bit.

item.title: Company apologizes after AI support agent invents policy that causes user uproar
item.description: Frustrated software developer believed AI-generated message came from human support rep.

item.title: Wait, what is agentic AI?
item.description: Is “agentic AI” just a buzzword, or is it the sea change it seems?

item.title: OpenAI releases new simulated reasoning models with full tool access
item.description: New o3 model appears "near-genius level," according to one doctor, but it still makes mistakes.

item.title: Engineering teams need to adapt to AI’s scaling challenges
item.description: AI is not a linear process. To scale effectively, engineering leaders must account for varied edge cases, presenting a new set of challenges.

item.title: Researchers claim breakthrough in fight against AI’s frustrating security hole
item.description: Prompt injections are the Achilles' heel of AI assistants. Google offers a potential fix.

item.title: WBIT #7: Exploring WebAssembly with the first SO user to get 10k rep
item.description: Kyle interviews Michael Stum, a former Stacker who started (and returned) to answering questions on the community site.

item.title: 4chan has been down since Monday night after “pretty comprehensive own”
item.description: Early info is unreliable, but the site has been mostly unavailable for hours.

item.title: Smarter insights, stronger teams: New features for Stack Overflow for Teams
item.description: 2025.3 | Teams Enterprise Release

item.title: How AI can prevent clinician burnout
item.description: In today’s episode, Ryan sits down with Richard “Spencer” Schaefer, cofounder and CTO of Lunar Analytics and a federal AI officer, and Caroline Zhang, cofounder and CTO of Knowtex, which provides AI-powered voice technology to automate workflows. They talk about safeguarding patient privacy, how AI changes doctor-patient interactions and healthcare delivery, the challenges inherent in rolling out AI technology, and the importance of quality data to fuel AI initiatives. Also included: a chat with Jeff Berkowitz, cofounder and CEO of Delve Deep Learning.

item.title: OpenAI continues naming chaos despite CEO acknowledging the habit
item.description: OpenAI's brand-new "GPT-4.1" has a funky name but reasonable performance for the price.

item.title: Amid Trump tariff chaos, Nvidia launches AI chip production on US soil
item.description: New announcement seems aimed at appeasing Trump, signals company shift.

item.title: Like self-driving cars, fully AI-automated sysadmins don't exist
item.description: As with cars, there are few system administration tasks that involve little to no automation.

item.title: That groan you hear is users’ reaction to Recall going back into Windows
item.description: Snapshotting and AI processing a screen every 3 seconds. What could possibly go wrong?

item.title: Researcher uncovers dozens of sketchy Chrome extensions with 4 million installs
item.description: Even weirder: Why would Google give so many the "Featured" stamp for trustworthiness?

item.title: How do you fact-check an AI?
item.description: Ryan chats with Amr Awadallah, founder and CEO of GenAI platform Vectara about how retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) has advanced, why fact-checking and accurate data are essential in building AI applications, and how Vectara’s Mockingbird model seeks to minimize hallucinations.

item.title: Researchers concerned to find AI models misrepresenting their “reasoning” processes
item.description: New Anthropic research shows AI models often fail to disclose reasoning shortcuts.

item.title: “There is a real cost to moving fast”: Using AI to accelerate drug discovery
item.description: On this episode of Leaders of Code, Maureen Makes, VP of Engineering at Recursion, discusses AI's role in drug discovery, scaling and integration challenges, and the importance of innovation in achieving the high standards desired.

item.title: OpenAI helps spammers plaster 80,000 sites with messages that bypassed filters
item.description: Company didn't notice its chatbot was being abused for (at least) 4 months.

item.title: After months of user complaints, Anthropic debuts new $200/month AI plan
item.description: Two-tiered "Claude Max" expands rate limits and offers traffic priority to subscribers.

item.title: WBIT #6: Be curious, ask questions, and don’t argue with JavaScript
item.description: Kyle chats with Jesse Tomchak a software engineer at ClickUp about all the spicy backend takes they could find.

item.title: “The girl should be calling men.” Leak exposes Black Basta’s influence tactics.
item.description: Disclosure of tactics, techniques, and procedures provides rare glimpse into secretive group.

item.title: Carmack defends AI tools after Quake fan calls Microsoft AI demo “disgusting”
item.description: Carmack: "Power tools" like AI are "central to all the progress in computers."

item.title: Bottom of the first: A veteran VC’s take on the AI landscape
item.description: Ryan welcomes Tomasz Tunguz of Theory Ventures back to the podcast to talk about the intersection of AI and venture capital, the implications of AI on the labor market, and the future of AI applications.

item.title: Meta’s surprise Llama 4 drop exposes the gap between AI ambition and reality
item.description: Touted 10M token context proves elusive, while early performance tests disappoint experts.

item.title: Open-source AI: Are younger developers leading the way?
item.description: In March, over 1,000 developers and technologists gave us insights into what they think about open source and the role it plays with AI.

item.title: NSA warns “fast flux” threatens national security. What is fast flux anyway?
item.description: Used by nation-states and crime groups, fast flux bypasses many common defenses.

item.title: Using GenAI as a learning tool, not a crutch
item.description: AI is changing how we think about coding. While tools evolve, critical thinking, problem-solving, and creativity remain the essential skills for top developers.

item.title: Is AI a bubble or a revolution? The answer is yes.
item.description: At HumanX 2025, Ryan sat down with HumanX CEO Stefan Weitz and Crunchbase CEO Jager McConnell to talk about where the money is in the AI space, where most enterprise AI strategies fall short, how companies can build business models when AI tech is evolving so quickly, and why this is AI’s microservices moment.

item.title: From training to inference: The new role of web data in LLMs
item.description: Data has always been key to LLM success, but it's becoming key to inference-time performance as well.

item.title: Not all AI is generative: Efficient scheduling with mathematics
item.description: Efficiently solving a complex scheduling problem using simulated annealing.

item.title: Boots on the ground: Holistic AI and Audioshake at HumanX
item.description: Two interviews for the price of one, direct from HumanX 2025! Ryan sits down with Raj Patel, AI transformation lead at Holistic AI, and then chats with Audioshake cofounder and CEO Jessica Powell.

item.title: “Are AI agents ready for the enterprise?”
item.description: Deepak Singh, VP of Developer Agents and Experiences at AWS, helps Ryan break down the hype around agentic AI in software development. They cover the definition and real-world functionality of AI agents, how developers can integrate them into existing workflows, and the importance of establishing guardrails to ensure trust and security in agentic AI.

item.title: AI is shifting focus from syntax to critical thinking
item.description: In this episode of Leaders of Code, host Ben Popper, Stack Overflow CEO Prashanth Chandrasekar, and GitLab Field CTO Lee Faus explore how GenAI is reshaping software development practices.

item.title: “The power of the humble embedding”
item.description: Ryan speaks with Edo Liberty, Founder and CEO of Pinecone, about building vector databases, the power of embeddings, the evolution of RAG, and fine-tuning AI models.

item.title: An AI future free of slop
item.description: Stack Overflow CEO Prashanth Chandrasekar sat down with Ryan at HumanX 2025 to talk about how Stack is integrating AI into its public platform, the enormous importance of a high-quality knowledge base in your AI journey, how AI tools are empowering junior developers to build better software, and much more.

item.title: WBIT #5: Building a framework to lure web devs to mobile
item.description: Kyle interviews Maria Hutt about building the Ionic mobile framework.

item.title: Improving error monitoring with AI
item.description: Tillman Elser, AI/ML lead at Sentry, joins Ryan for a conversation about improving error monitoring with AI and ML. They talk through the challenges of analyzing stack traces, the innovative use of embeddings to improve error grouping, the trial-and-error process of developing algorithms, and where Sentry’s AI capabilities are headed next.

item.title: To get ahead with AI, fine-tune your data strategy
item.description: In the first episode of our new podcast series, Leaders of Code, we sat down with Don Woodlock, Head of Global Healthcare Solutions at InterSystems, and Stack Overflow CEO Prashanth Chandrasekar to discuss data strategy's critical role in AI development.

item.title: What we learned at TDX 2025
item.description: Some high-level takeaways, with more to come.

item.title: Can climate tech startups address the current crisis?
item.description: Lisbeth Kaufman, Head of Climate Tech at AWS, sits down with Ryan to talk about her work helping climate tech startups get off the ground and the role startups can play in addressing the climate change crisis. She highlights a few projects to get excited about, including ones focused on fusion energy and sustainable agriculture.

item.title: Junky data is like an out-of-tune guitar—it prevents AI harmony
item.description: In our very first episode, Stack Overflow CEO Prashanth Chandrasekar talks to Don Woodlock, Head of Global Healthcare Solutions at InterSystems, about the challenges in their AI journey and the critical role of a robust data strategy in any successful AI initiative.

item.title: A look under the hood: How (and why) we built Question Assistant
item.description: Evaluating question quality and determining the appropriate feedback required some classic ML techniques in addition to our GenAI solution.

item.title: Sharing the power of the command line
item.description: Ryan welcomes Zach Lloyd, founder and CEO of Warp, to the show to talk about reimagining the terminal. They also discuss why Warp was built in Rust (“it’s definitely harder”), how AI is transforming developer tools, and what Zach (formerly a principal engineer at Google) learned building Docs and Sheets.

item.title: How are sandwich generation developers dealing?
item.description: More developers are sandwiched between caring for kids and older relatives. What does this mean for them and for the industry as a whole?

item.title: Is Postgres the best database for GenAI?
item.description: Jeremy “Jezz” Kellway, VP of Engineering for Analytics and Data & AI at EDB (Enterprise Database), joins Ryan for a conversation about Postgres and AI. They unpack how Postgres is becoming the standard database for AI applications, the importance of managing unstructured data, and the implications of data sovereignty and governance in AI.

item.title: How can AI perform on the edge?
item.description: What are the capabilities, constraints, and benefits of running AI models on edge devices?

item.title: Boosting collaboration and control: New features for Stack Overflow for Teams
item.description: Our latest Enterprise release brings exciting new features designed to enhance collaboration, streamline user management, and expand API capabilities.

item.title: Secure coding beyond just memory safety
item.description: Software security expert Tanya Janca, author of Alice and Bob Learn Secure Coding and Staff DevRel at AppSec company Semgrep, joins Ryan to talk about secure coding practices.

item.title: “Translation is the tip of the iceberg”: A deep dive into specialty models
item.description: Olga Beregovaya, VP of AI at Smartling, joins Ryan and Ben to explore the evolution and specialization of language models in AI.

item.title: Our next phase—Q&A was just the beginning
item.description: For those that missed our February AMA, let’s discuss the future of Stack Overflow
